search.slidetext: principles of soil mechanics and aggregate production unit 1: rock and soil material unit 1: rock and soil material unit 1: rock and soil material unit 2: aggregate production unit 2: aggregate production unit 2: aggregate production unit 3: soil material relationships unit 3: soil material relationships unit 3: soil material relationships unit 4: soil compaction unit 4: soil compaction unit 4: soil compaction

soil heavy construction operations mainly involve earthwork operations. rock material soil material rock material rock is a solid natural element, which consists one or more minerals. soil material unconsolidated particles in the crust of earth and rock
rock material rock is a solid natural element, which consists one or more minerals. three major classes of rock: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.
rock material lava magma igneous rocks are the initial rocks formed from the cooling and solidification of molten material, including magma and lava.

material rock igneous rocks could be classified by the rate of cooling. basalt rapid-cooling material form fine-grained rocks granite slow-cooling material create coarse-grained rocks hover over me! hover over me!

rock material sediment formed by: weathering and erosion transported by: water wind ice mass movement glaciers sedimentary rocks formed by: solidification of sediments sediment sediment compression compression sedimentary rock (hover for example) examples: limestone, dolomite, shale

material rock metamorphic rocks are the result of transformation of pre-existing rocks, such as igneous, sedimentary, or another older metamorphic rocks. pressure from above layers sedimentary or igneous rock heat from lower layers examples: slate, marble, gneiss (hover)

rock material tendency of material to break into smaller pieces under duress or contact friable indurate (hard) marble recrystallization under intense heat and pressure shale metamorphic rocks sedimentary rocks

importance of rock identification in heavy construction 1. excavation method 2. use of rock material for aggregate production drill and blast, hard rocks rippability, sedimentary rocks watch drill and blast in action

soil material soil includes mineral particles and organic material. mineral particles are the result of physical or chemical weathering of rocks organic material originated from the remains of organisms (e.g. plants and animals) and their waste products in the environment soil can also contain liquids and gas

mineral particles of the soil could be classified based on the grain sizes. soil material particles grain size gravel (coarse aggregate) larger than 4.75 mm (5 mm in canadian standard) sand (fine aggregate) smaller than 4.75 mm (5 mm in canadian standard) and larger than 0.075 mm silt and clay (fines) smaller than 0.075 mm sample silt clay 0.002 mm

summary of unit 1 igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic are three main types of rock. 2. identification of the rock type is important in heavy civil operations. 3. soil samples are used to determine the grain-size distribution (gradation).

material aggregate aggregates are processed granular mineral particles (including soil and rock). backfill roadbase portland cement
sources aggregate sources 1. natural sand and gravel deposits fine aggregate coarse aggregate gravel pieces on beach natural sand natural gravel
sources aggregate see how crushed aggregate particles are made! see how a jaw crusher works!
sources aggregate other sources of aggregate: slag and mine refuse rubble and refuse artificial and process materials pulverized concrete and asphalt pavement other recycled and waste materials

quiz friction is an important property in asphalt concrete pavements (for road safety). which one of the following aggregate types is better for asphalt concrete production? natural aggregate natural aggregate natural aggregate crushed aggregate crushed aggregate crushed aggregate pulverized concrete pulverized concrete pulverized concrete

strength aggregate essential strength property = ability of aggregate layers to sustain load without particles sliding over each other. main factor = friction between grains and how well they are interlocked. fig a. fig b. fig c. load sharp edges high friction; improved sliding resistance densely graded gaps filled with fine aggregates; more sliding resistance
gradation aggregate is one of the most important properties of aggregates grain-size distribution must provide a dense and strong mixture.

gradation curve (% of mixture through sieve size) gradation aggregate (a) theoretical maximum density (b) uniform (single size) aggregate (c) gap-graded aggregates (d) open-graded aggregates click on a curve name to learn more!
aggregate gradation

summary of unit 2 1. natural and crushed aggregates are two main aggregate sources 2. shape of the aggregate particles plays a key role in the strength of a layer 3. gradation is one of the most important properties of aggregate and contributes to the strength of the mix

weight volume relationships soil material

weight volume relationships soil material unit weight (y) = = total weight w total volume v dry unit weight (y ) = = soil particles w total volume v s d water content (w) = = weight of water in soil w weight of soil particles w w s porosity (n) = = voids volume v total volume v v void ratio (e) = = volume of voids v soil volume v v s

volumetric measure depending on the position of earth material in the construction process, the volumetric measure varies. bank volume => natural condition loose volume => after excavation, during loading and hauling compacted volume => after mechanical compaction, also called “net in-place”.
volumetric measure bank volume loose volume bank volume < loose volume
loose volume compacted volume volumetric measure compacted volume < bank volume < loose volume
volumetric measure shrinkage factor shrinkage factor = compacted dry unit weight bank dry unit weight shrinkage % = (compacted dry unit weight) - (bank unit weight) compacted unit weight x 100
volumetric measure swell factor swell factor = loose dry unit weight bank dry unit weight swell % = bank dry unit weight loose dry unit weight -1 x 100 ( )

volumetric measure: exercise an embankment will have a net volume of 145000 cubic meter after compaction. the borrow material has a wet unit weight of 2060 kg per cubic meter, water content of 16.5%, and in-place void ratio (e) of 0.62 in bank condition. the thickness of embankment layer is 20 cm with dry unit weight of 1830 kg per cubic meter and water content of 18.3%. calculate the volume of excavation in the borrow pit.

volumetric measure solution view question see question view question see question view question dry unit weight (y ) = = soil particles w total volume v s d shrinkage factor = compacted dry unit weight bank dry unit weight required equations calculations y of borrow material = = 1768 kg/m3 2060 (1 +0.165) d y of fill material = 1830 kg/m3 d shrinkage factor = = 1.035 1768 1830 145,000 × 1.035 = 150,075 m3 required from borrow pit

volumetric measure solution con’t view question see question view question see question view question water content calculations water in fill material = 145,000 x 1830 x 0.183 = 48,559,050 kg water in borrow material = 150,075 x 1768 x 0.165 = 43,779,880 kg required water (difference) = 4,779,170 kg or 31.85 liter per cubic meter of borrow material

summary of unit 3 1. soil is a mixture of solid particles, liquid (usually water), and gas. 2. calculation of the soil unit weights based on the water content and voids. 3. soil swells after excavation (loose volume), and can be compacted to a smaller volume than the original (bank volume) state.

compaction compacted grains loose grains
compaction benefits increases strength of soil reduces settlements increase bearing capacity control volume changes reduce permeability

compaction curve essential test to achieve suitable compaction levels represent dry density against the water content of test samples past the optimum level, water replaces soil grains, increasing voids, reduces the dry density of the compacted layer
compaction tests compaction force = 4.5x larger
compaction tests nuclear densometer - measures density of embankment layers
soil compaction factors 1. required amount of water 2. rate of adding water 3. method of water addition 4. weather conditions

soil compaction factors 1. required amount of water (desired water content%) amount of water = (water content in borrow%) target dry density x _ 100 * increase desired water content for 2% above the optimum, as the water may evaporate during process

quiz 1. required amount of water the desired dry unit weight of the fill is 1920 kg per cubic metre. according to the compaction test, the optimum moisture content (omc) is 12%, and the water content of the material is 5%. the embankment layer will be 15 cm and 12.2 metre wide. calculate the amount of water required for every 100 meter of embankment. view equation 32,000 liters 32,000 liters 32,000 liters 27,500 liters 27,500 liters 27,500 liters 24,600 liters 24,600 liters 24,600 liters

quiz: solution 1. required amount of water the desired dry unit weight of the fill is 1920 kg per cubic metre. according to the compaction test, the optimum moisture content (omc) is 12%, and the water content of the material is 5%. the embankment layer will be 15 cm and 12.2 metre wide. calculate the amount of water required for every 100 meter of embankment. view equation solution 12 5 1920 x _ 100 x = 24595 = 24,600 liters 0.15 x 12.2 x 100

quiz 2: solution 2. rate of adding of water what is the application rate water for the previous question (required water was 24,600 litres for 12.2x100 meter area) ? view equation solution 24,6000 20.16 = 20.2 litre/m2 required water area 12.2 x100 = =
soil compaction factors 2. rate of adding of water (% of moisture added) thickness of the compacted lift litres per square meter target dry density x 100 x =

quiz 2 2. rate of adding of water what is the application rate water for the previous question (required water was 24,600 litres for 12.2x100 metre area) ? view equation 18.5 liter/m2 18.5 liter/m2 18.5 liter/m2 20.2 liter/m2 20.2 liter/m2 20.2 liter/m2 22 liter/m2 22 liter/m2 22 liter/m2
soil compaction factors 3. method of water addition watch water tank in action watch water tank in action watch water tank in action
soil compaction factors 4. weather conditions soil retains moisture cold rainy cloudy calm increased evaporation hot dry sunny windy

compaction methods static weight pressure abrupt blows impact vibration rearrange grains kneading material not effective very high high low gravel not effective high excellent low sand high excellent low high silt very high high not effective excellent (if confined) clay
compaction methods smooth drum vibratory roller vibratory tamping foot roller image placeholder for sheep foot roller sheep foot roller pneumatic roller

compaction equipment smooth vibratory tamping foot vibration kneading effective not effective not effective effective rock boulders effective acceptable acceptable effective gravel effective acceptable (not if sand is clean) not effective effective sand material acceptable effective effective effective silt acceptable effective effective effective clay

summary of unit 4 1. compaction curve is an important tool to determine the optimum level of water content for soil compaction. 2. standard and modified proctor tests are common methods to determine the compaction curve of a soil type. 3. pressure, impact, vibration, kneading of soil grains, or a combination of these methods can be used for soil compaction. 4. none of these methods is effective in all types of soil and the effectiveness of the compaction approach depends on the soil properties. 5. proper compaction equipment should be selected accordingly.

summary of module 2 recognition of rock type is essential in heavy civil operations bank, loose, and compact volumes are required to plan for earthmoving operations grain-size distribution (gradation) of soil should be determined selection of compaction method based on soil classification results calculation of the compaction curve using test samples to determine optimum water content selection of proper compaction equipment

module 2 quiz 1. which one of the three types of rocks are generally weaker than the other two? igneous igneous igneous sedimentary sedimentary sedimentary metamorphic metamorphic metamorphic
2. which one of following gradations provides a stronger layer? figure a. figure a. figure a. figure b. figure b. figure b. figure c. figure c. figure c. module 2 quiz

3. an excavation volume for a foundation is estimated to be 750 bank cubic meters. how many truckloads should you expect to haul away the excavated material? assume that a truck can carry 9 m3 and that the swell factor for this material is 0.87. 84 89 96 module 2 quiz

96 the weight of total excavated material is equal in bank and loose states. 750 x bank density = v(loose) x (bank density x 0.87) v(loose) = 862 cubic meters truckloads = 862/9 = 96 3. an excavation volume for a foundation is estimated to be 750 bank cubic meters. how many truckloads should you expect to haul away the excavated material? assume that a truck can carry 9 m3 and that the swell factor for this material is 0.87. solution module 2 quiz solution
4. select proper equipment for compaction of a gravel layer. drag and drop each piece of equipment to its effectiveness level. effective effective acceptable not effective module 2 quiz

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
In Unit 1: You will be able to classify different categories of rocks and their origin, including igneous rocks, sedimentary rocks, thermal metamorphic rocks, and stress metamorphic rocks, You will be able to explain components of soil and their main properties.

In Unit 2: You will be able to discuss aggregate sources, types, and properties, You will be able to compare different aggregate gradations.

In Unit 3: You will be able to explain and apply the concepts of unit weight, swelling, compaction, and volume capacity as they related to heavy civil engineering projects.

In Unit 4: You will be able to relate the relationship between water content and compaction level, You will be able to explain the factors influencing the method and level of soil compaction, You will be able to discuss different compaction equipment and their effectiveness in different soil types

Heavy construction operations mainly involve earthwork operations. Therefore, it is essential to identify earth materials in jobsites and design methods and select appropriate equipment accordingly. Earth materials are generally classified into: Rock material and soil material.

Rock material are solid natural elements, which consists one or more minerals whereas soil material are unconsolidated particles in the crust of earth.

As described, Rocks consist one or more minerals.

Depending on their creation mechanism, rocks are classified into three major classes, including: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.

Igneous rocks are the initial rocks formed from the cooling and solidification of molten material, including magma and lava.

Magma is the molten material inside the and the lava is the molten material which came out of the crest due to volcanic activities.

Igneous rocks could be classified based on the rate of cooling.

Rapid-cooling material form fine-grained rocks, such as basalt, and slow-cooling material create coarse-grained rocks, e.g. granite.

Coarse grains are noticeable in the left image whereas the grains in the right samples are fine and difficult to distinguish.

Sediments, including organic particles and minerals, which formed by weathering and erosion from the source area are transported by water, wind, ice, mass movement or glaciers, to the place of deposition.

Sedimentary rocks are formed from the solidification of the sediments deposited under the bodies of water.

Limestone, dolomite, and shale are some examples of sedimentary rocks.

Metamorphic rocks are the result of transformation of pre-existing rocks, such as igneous, sedimentary, or another older metamorphic rocks. These rocks are transformed by intense heat and/or pressure.

Slate (from shale), marble (from limestone), and gneiss (from granite) are some examples of metamorphic rocks.

Depending on the formation conditions of rocks, they could be hard or friable. Friability is tendency of a rack material to break into smaller pieces under duress or contact, specially rubbing. The opposite of friable is called indurate.

Due to recrystallization under intense heat and pressure, metamorphic rocks are indurate and hard.

In contrast, some sedimentary rocks are friable and are not suitable choice for some construction applications, e.g. use in concrete production.

It is very important in heavy civil engineering operations to identify the types of the rocks. Some of the most important reasons are:

1- Selection of excavation method

Igneous and metamorphic rocks are generally hard and difficult to rip. Powerful equipment and special techniques, such as drill and blast, are required to breakdown and remove these types of rocks. In contrast, friable and low-strength rocks could be excavated using heavy bulldozers equipped with ripper shank. The rippability of a rock material is a measure of its ability to be excavated with mechanical excavation equipment

2- Identify suitable rock material for aggregate production in close proximity to a heavy construction project

It is critical to assess the origin of bedrock for production aggregate, as it determines physical properties and chemical reactivity of the aggregate particles

For example, some applications, such as asphalt concrete, require hard aggregates, and some others, such light-weight concretes, need low density aggregates

• Soil includes mineral particles and organic material.

• Mineral particles are the result of physical or chemical weathering of rocks.

• Organic material originated from the remains of organisms (e.g. plants and animals) and their waste products in the environment.

• Soil can also contain liquids and gas .

Mineral particles of the soil could be classified based on the grain sizes.

The smaller particles are sand.

Silt and clay grains are very small. As presented in this figure, silt particles have spherical or cubical shapes, whereas clay grains are flat and plate-shape.

Clay particles are generally smaller than silt particles, and in addition, they exhibit plasticity properties of the soil, as measured by the soils' Atterberg limits.

Summary of the items discussed in this Unit:

• Igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic are three main types of rock

• Identification of the rock type is important in heavy civil operations

• Soil samples are used to determine the grain-size distribution (gradation).

Aggregates are processed granular mineral particles (including soil and rock) which are used either alone, such as backfill, road bases and sub-bases, or in combination with a cementing material, such as Portland cement and asphalt to form concretes.

There are several source for aggregate production, but two of them are the most important ones:

First source include natural sand and gravel deposits.

Sand and gravel particles that are naturally sorted to eliminate silt and clay and then deposited in stream bed and along the beaches of lakes and seas.

The sand grains are also called fine aggregate and the gravel particles are commonly called coarse aggregate.

The grains in left side of the figure are natural sand, and the larger particles in the right side are natural gravel .

Second important aggregate source is crushed rocks.

Crushed aggregate particles are produced through mining a rock quarry, usually by drilling and blasting, and then crushing the rock fragments into the desired sizes using crushers.

Different types of crushers are used to reduce large rocks into smaller aggregate particles.

Jaw crusher, gyratory crushers, and cone crusher are some examples of industrial crusher.

This figure shows the mechanism used in a typical jaw crusher.

There are also other sources of aggregate, which have considerably smaller proportion than the other two in the industry.

These sources, however, are much more sustainable and aimed at reducing landfill by using recycled construction material or waste and recycled materials from other industries, such as mining.

The most important examples include:

• Slag and mine refuse

• Rubble and refuse

• Artificial and process materials

• Pulverized concrete and asphalt pavement

Friction is an important property in asphalt concrete pavements (for road safety). Which one of the following aggregate types is better for asphalt concrete production.

a. Natural aggregate

b. Crushed aggerate

c. Pulverized concrete

The ability of a layer of aggregates to sustain load without particles sliding over each other is an essential strength property.

A main factor in the strength of a layer of aggregate is the friction between the grains and how well they are interlocked.

As it is presented in figure a, aggregate particles distribute the applied loads both horizontally and vertically and excessive load can result in sliding. The magnitude of the applied load is significantly reduced as it distributed over a large area, thus, substantial surface loads can be carried by the underlying aggregate layer without failure.

This figure (B) shows crushed aggregate with sharp edges which provide high friction and improves the resistance against sliding.

Densely graded layers, in Figure C, in which the gaps are filled with fine aggregates, could provide more resistance against sliding.

The grain-size distribution, commonly known as Aggregate Gradation, a is one of the most important properties of an aggregate mix.

Most heavy construction applications, such as highway base, cement concrete, and asphalt concrete, require dense and strong aggregate mixtures.

Mechanical shaker is commonly used for sieve analysis to determine aggregate gradation.

The results of sieve analysis is presented in the for of gradation curve, which represents the percent of the mixture passing a certain sieve size.

In this figure:

Curves (a) show theoretical maximum density curves where a well-distributed of aggregate particles exist in the mix.

Curve (b) illustrates uniform aggregate gradation, in which the majority of aggregate particles have a same size.

Curve (c) shows gap-graded aggregates, in which the mix contain certain size grains and lacks the other sizes.

Curve (d) demonstrates open-graded aggregates.

Industrial aggregate screening systems use pressurized water spray to clean aggregates from deleterious material, such as dust, clay, and organic material, and employ series of vibrating screens and conveyors to produce aggregate according to gradation specifications.

• Natural and crushed aggerates are two main aggregate sources.

• Shape of the aggregate particles plays a key role in the strength of a layer.

• Gradation is one of the most important properties of aggregate and contributes to the strength of the mix.

As mentioned before, soil usually includes solid particles, liquid (mainly water), and gases, mainly air. The weight an volume composition of the soil can be visualized like this, and each of the components has their corresponding weight and volume. The weight of the air is too small compared to water and solid particles, so it is considered as zero.

Combination of the air and water volumes is the volume that is not occupied by solid particles and called voids volume .

Using the variables introduced, we can derive useful relationships:

Unit weight equals to the total weight of the soil divided by its total volume

Dry unit weight equals to the weight of the solid particles divided by total volume

Water content percentage equals to the weight of the water in the soil divided by the weight of the solid particles

Porosity percentage equals to the void volume in the soil divided by the total volume

And finally, Void ratio equals to the void volume in the soil divided by the volume of the solid particles

Depending on the position of earth material in the construction process, the volumetric measure varies.

First, Bank volume is the volume of the soil in the natural condition.

Second, Loose volume which is the volume of the same weight, but after excavation and during loading and hauling. Due to the disturbance in the proportions of the soil component, soil material swell after excavation.

Finally, Compacted volume is the volume of the soil after mechanical compaction, also called net in-place.

This figure shows the bank volume in the natural state and swelled soil after excavation, which is called loose volume.

Loose volume of the certain weight of soil is greater than its bank volume

This figure represents loose volume during hauling and the compacted volume after mechanical compaction.

Loose volume of the certain weight of soil is greater than its compacted volume.

Shrinkage factor of the soil after compaction can be calculated using the following formula:

Shrinkage factor equals to the compacted dry unit weight divided by the bank dry unit weight.

Shrinkage percentage equals to the compacted dry unit weight minus bank unit weight divided by the compacted unit weight multiplied by 100.

Swell factor of the natural soil after excavation can be calculated using the following formula:

Swell factor equals to the loose dry unit weight divided by the bank dry unit weight.

Swell percentage equals to the bank dry unit weight divided by loose dry unit weight minus 1 multiplied by 100.

Exercise

An embankment will have a net volume of 145000 cubic meter after compaction. The borrow material has a wet unit weight of 2060 kg per cubic meter, water content of 16.5%, and in-place void ratio (e) of 0.62 in bank condition. The thickness of embankment layer is 20 cm with dry unit weight of 1830 kg per cubic meter and water content of 18.3%. Calculate the volume of excavation in the borrow pit.

First we can calculate unit dry weight of the borrow material using it wet unit weight and water content,

Given the unit dry weight of the fill material, we can calculate the Shrinkage Factor. Thus, using the shrinkage factor and the required compacted volume, the required volume from the borrow pit is calculated.

The water content should be calculated as well:

The next step is to calculate the needed water in the fill material.

Then the existing water in the borrow material is calculated.

The required water is the difference of the required and existing water.

Summary of Unit 3

• Soil is a mixture of solid particles, liquid (usually water), and gas.

• Calculation of the soil unit weights based on the water content and voids.

• Soil swells after excavation (loose volume), and can be compacted to a smaller volume than the original (bank volume) state.

Soil compaction is the process of applying stress to a soil layer which displaces air from the voids between the soil grains and results in densification of the layer.

As presented here, mechanical equipment are commonly used for compaction of the soil. The compacted sample in the left image presents much denser composition of soil grains compared to the loose grains in the right image.

Compaction improves the following properties of the soil:

• It increases the strength of the soil

• It reduces settlements

• Compaction increases bearing capacity

• It is used to control volume changes

• And lastly, it reduces permeability of the soil

Water content plays a key role for optimum compaction.

Therefore, compaction curves are used to represent dry density against the water content of test samples.

Compaction curve is an essential test to achieve suitable compaction levels.

In this figure, two curves are presented and each of theses two curve is the result of a one type of experiment.

In both methods, the dry density of the soil increases by increasing the water content, because adding water lubricates soil grains and facilitates densification of the soil through compaction process. However, after a certain water content, about 16.5% in the standard proctor sample in this figure, the density starts to drop. Because the water content has passes the optimum level and instead of working as a lubrication film, it starts to replace soil grains and therefore increases the voids and reduces the dry density of the compacted layer.

Both compaction tests are illustrated here.

In the standard proctor test in the left side, a 5.5 lb weight is used to compact three layers of soil sample, where each layer is compacted by the weight released 25 times from 12 inches.

The configuration of the modified proctor test is rather similar, but the modified proctor test uses heavier weight, which is 10 lb, and higher drop levels, thus the compaction force is much larger than the force used in the standard proctor test. The compaction force in the modified test is about 4.5 times larger than the force applied in the standard test. That is the main reason why larger densities are achieved in the modified proctor test.

There are also advanced instruments to test the compaction of a soil layer in-place.

Nuclear densometer is a common equipment that is used in the heavy construction industry, namely highway construction, to measure the density of the embankment layers in place.

This instrument uses the gamma-ray scattering in the material to measure density, either by direct transmission or the backscatter method.

The following factors should be considered before starting compaction process:

1. Required amount of water

2. Rate of adding water

3. Method of water addition

4. And Weather conditions

The most important factor is to estimate the required amount of water.

To estimate the required amount of water, we need to have desired water content from proctor test and also measure the water content in the borrow are. The we can measure the required amount of water using this formula.

It is a common practice to increase the desired water content for 2% above the optimum, because a portion of water might evaporate during the process, but it depends on the soil type and weather condition.

Quiz

The desired dry unit weight of the fill is 1920 kg per cubic meter. According to the compaction test, the optimum moisture content (OMC) is 12%, and the water content of the material is 5%. The embankment layer will be 15 cm and 12.2 meter wide. Calculate the amount of water required for every 100 meter of embankment.

The third important factor is to determine method of water addition to the soil.

In these methods, water is sprayed on the water using water tankers installed on trucks.

Ponding is another approach for adding water, but it is less common compared to using water tankers.

4. Weather conditions

· Weather condition during compaction can considerably affect the moisture content.

· Cold, rainy, cloudy, and calm weather => retains moisture

· Hot, dry, sunny, and windy weather => increases evaporation rate, might need to increase moisture above the optimum level

Compaction of soil is typically achieved trough a mechanical process. Mechanical compaction of the soil can be done either by:

• Pressure by applying static weight

• Impact by applying abrupt blow

• Vibration

• Kneading by rearrange soil grains

• A combination of the above methods

But, none of these methods is effective in all types of soul and depending on the component of the soil, we have to select an effective solution. This table summarizes compaction methods and their effectiveness in different soil materials

Roller are the most common equipment used for compaction of the soil. Rollers have a number subclasses and each of the subclasses is able to provide one or more type of compaction method, and therefore is suitable for compaction of certain types of soil.

As mentioned before, effective compaction methods should be selected based on the soil material. Since the mentioned equipment are able provide one, two, or three compaction methods, therefore, each roller type is effective in certain type of soil.

In practice, there are several areas that roller can not be used, such as small areas and confined zone where the roller can not operate or it is not feasible to transport a roller there. Moreover, rollers might not be able to compact soil close to sensitive structures.

There are small compaction equipment which are useful for those areas.

This machine applies vibration for compaction of soil.

This machine applies impact and some level of vibration for compaction of soil.

Both of these equipment are manually guided and operated.

1. Compaction curve is an important tool to determine the optimum level of water content for soil compaction.

2. Standard and modified proctor tests are common methods to determine the compaction curve of a soil type.

3. Pressure, impact, vibration, kneading of soil grains, or a combination of these methods can be used for soil compaction.

4. Calculation of the compaction curve using test samples to determine optimum water content.

5. None of these methods is effective in all types of soil and the effectiveness of the compaction approach depends on the soil properties.

6. Proper compaction equipment should be selected accordingly.

• Recognition of rock type is essential in heavy civil operations

• Grain-size distribution (gradation) of soil should be determined

• Bank, loose, and compact volumes are required to plan for earthmoving operations

• Calculation of the compaction curve using test samples to determine optimum water content

• Selection of compaction method based on soil classification results

• Selection od proper compaction equipment
